sentences.sentence: September 30, 1659.—I, poor Robinson Crusoe, being shipwrecked( （因船只失事）遭海难 ) during a terrible storm, came on shore on this lonely, unfortunate island.
I call it the Island of Despair( 绝望 ).
All the rest of the ship’s company were drowned( 淹死 ), and I was almost dead.
I spent all the rest of the day worrying about the awful situation I was in.
I had neither food, house, clothes, weapons( 武器 ), nor place to run to.
In despair( 绝望 ) of any relief, I saw nothing but death before me.
I was certain I would be eaten by wild beasts, murdered by natives, or starved( 挨饿的 ) to death for lack of food.
At the approach of night I slept in a tree, for fear of( 唯恐… ) wild creatures, but slept soundly( 睡得很香 ), though it rained all night.
October 1.—In the morning, I saw, to my great surprise, that the ship had floated much nearer to the island.
At length( 最终 ), seeing the ship was almost dry, I went upon the sand as near as I could, and then swam on board.
From the 1st of October to the 24th.—All these days entirely spent in many voyages to get all I could out of the ship, which I brought to shore upon rafts( 木筏 ).
Oct. 25.—It rained all night and all day, with some strong wind, during which time the ship broke in pieces.
I spent this day in covering and securing the goods which I had saved, that the rain might not spoil( 损坏 ) them.
Oct. 26.—I walked along the shore almost all day, to find a place to fix my shelter( 住所 ).
I was greatly concerned to secure myself from any attack in the night, either from wild beasts or men.
Towards night, I settled upon a proper place, under a rock, and marked out a half a circle for my tent.
I decided to strengthen it with a wall.
From the 26th to the 30th I worked very hard in carrying all my goods to my new shelter( 住所 ), though some part of the time it rained very hard.
The 31st, in the morning, I went out into the island with my gun, to seek for some food, and explore the country.
I killed a goat.
November 1.—I set up my tent under a rock, and lay there for the first night.
Nov. 2.—I set up all my boxes and boards, and with them formed a fence round me.
Nov. 3.—I went out with my gun, and killed two birds like ducks, which were very good eating.
In the afternoon, I went to work to make myself a table.
Nov. 4.—The working part of this day and of the next were entirely used in making my table, for I was still a very poor workman.
Nov. 5.—This day I went out with my gun and my dog, and killed a wild cat.
Coming back by the shore, I saw many sorts of sea birds.
Nov. 6.—After my morning walk, I went to work on my table again.
I finished it, though not to my liking( 合某人心意的 ).
Nov. 7.—The 7th, 8th, 9th, 10th, and part of the 12th, I tried to make a chair, but it did not turn out the way I wanted.
Even while making it, I pulled it to pieces several times.
Nov. 13.—This day it rained, which refreshed( 使精神抖擞 ) me, but there was also terrible thunder and lightning.
This frightened me terribly for fear of my gunpowder( 火药 ).
As soon as it was over, I decided to separate my stock( 储备 ) of gunpowder( 火药 ) into as many little parcels as possible, that it might not be in danger.
Nov. 14, 15, 16.—These three days I spent in making little square boxes, which might hold about a pound or two of gunpowder( 火药 ).
On one of these three days I killed a large bird that was good to eat, but I did not know what to call it.
Nov. 17.—This day I began to dig behind my tent into the rock, to make room for( 为…留出余地 ) my further convenience( 方便 ).
Nov. 18.—The next day, in searching the woods, I found a tree, which in the Brazils they call the iron tree( 铁树 ), for its exceptional hardness.
With a lot of work, and almost spoiling( 损坏 ) my axe( 斧头 ), I cut a piece of it.
I brought it home, though with difficulty as well, for it was very heavy.
I worked it little by little into the form of a shovel( 铁铲 ).
However, with no iron at the bottom, it would not last me very long.
Nov. 23.—I spent eighteen days in widening and deepening my cave to hold my supplies.
December 10.—I began now to think my cave finished, when suddenly a great quantity of( 大量的 ) earth fell down from the top on one side.
It frightened me, for if I had been under it, I would have been buried alive( 活埋 ).
I had now a great deal of work to do over again.
I had the loose( 疏松的 ) earth to carry out, and the roof to support, so that I might be sure no more would come down.
In about a week more I had made the roof safe.
I used posts, standing in rows, which also served to form separate areas in the house.
Dec. 17.—From this day to the 20th I placed shelves, and knocked up nails on the posts, to hang everything up that could be hung up.
Dec. 20.—Now I carried everything into the cave, and began to furnish( 布置 ) my house. Also, I made another table.
Dec. 24.—Much rain all night and all day. No going out.
Dec. 25.—Rain all day.
Dec. 26.—No rain, and the earth was much cooler than before, and more pleasant.
Dec. 27.—Killed a young goat, and injured another, so that I caught it, and led it home on a string( 绳子 ).
When I had it at home, I fixed up its leg, which was broken.
Note.—I took such care of it that it lived, and the leg grew well and as strong as ever.
It grew tame( 温顺的 ), and fed upon( 以...为食 ) the little green at my door, and would not go away.
This was the first time that I thought of keeping some tame( 温顺的 ) animals, that I might have food when my gunpowder( 火药 ) and bullets( 子弹 ) were all used up.
Dec. 28, 29, 30.—Very hot, with no wind.
No going out, except in the evening, for food.
January 1.—Going farther into the valleys which lay towards the center of the island, I found there were plenty of goats.
Though they were very shy and hard to get at( 获得 ), I decided to try bringing my dog to hunt them down.
Jan. 2.—The next day I went out with my dog, and set him upon the goats.
But I was mistaken, for they all turned to face the dog, and he knew this danger too well, for he would not come near them.
Jan. 3.—I began my fence, or wall.
Being still fearful of being attacked by somebody, I decided to make it very thick and strong.
I worked on it from the 3rd of January to the 14th of April.
Note.—When this wall was finished, I thought that if any people were to come on shore there, they would not notice anything like a shelter( 住所 ).

article_info.previous: 前面我们读到Robinson渐渐习惯了独自在岛上的生活，为了保证自己的安全，他搭了帐篷挖了山洞。同时，他也开始思考如何在荒无一人的岛上真正地像现代人一样“生活”，而不是“生存”。

question.cn: Robinson的第一篇日记写了什么？
question.en: What was Robinson's first journal about?

options.cn: 他在岛上吃什么，住哪里。
options.en: What he ate and where he lived on the island.

options.cn: 他如何来到岛上的，以及上岛后的心情。
options.en: How he came to the island and how he felt.

analysis: 第一天的日记提到：“Being shipwrecked during a terrible storm, came on shore on this lonely, unfortunate island.”以及“I spent all the rest of the day worrying about the awful situation I was in. . . ”所以选C。

question.cn: Robinson为什么把盒子和木板堆起来？
question.en: Why did Robinson set up his boxes and boards?

options.en: Because there was no room for those things in the tent.

analysis: 文中说：“I set up all my boxes and boards, and with them formed a fence round me.”所以选B。

question.cn: 那只被Robinson救了的动物是什么？
question.en: What was the injured animal saved by Robinson?

analysis: 文中说：“Killed a young goat, and injured another...I fixed up its leg, which was broken.”因此选C。

question.en: What did Robinson do to his stock of gunpowder?

options.en: He put it in a large box.
He hid it under the rock.
He divided it into small parcels.

analysis: 文中说：“I decided to separate my stock of gunpowder into as many little parcels as possible, that it might not be in danger. ”所以选C。
